title: msp-grahame-launches-global-exhibition-holyrood
story: TWEEDDALE MSP Christine Grahame has launched a global exhibition inside the Scottish Parliament.The World Press Photo exhibition showcases some of the most powerful images from around the globe over the last year, and is a collection of award-winning photojournalism from .Images on display depict issues including perilous migrant journeys to the United States and the referendum on allowing abortions in Northern Ireland.The winning images were selected from over , entries, which were submitted by around , photographers based in  countries. These have been whittled down to the  images which are on display in Holyrood for the next month.The exhibition was unveiled by Deputy Presiding Officer Christine Grahame, who was joined by Yi Wen Hsia, from the World Press Photo Foundation, and Olivia Harris, a photographer whose work following the referendum on abortion in Ireland, is featured in the exhibition.Grahame said: ldquoThe Scottish Parliament is used to debating issues that go on to be front-page news in this country, but we need to remember the wider context in which we work.ldquoHaving the World Press Photo exhibition coming into our building is always a powerful reminder of the simultaneously awe-inspiring but sometimes awful world we live in, and the real stories behind the headlines.ldquoThe Scottish Parliament is the only location in the UK showing this free exhibition, and I encourage people to come and see it.Yi-Wen Hsia, Curator at World Press Photo, added:ldquoThe World Press Photo Foundation believes in the power of showing and the importance of seeing high-quality visual stories. Our mission is to connect the world to the stories that matter.ldquoWhen the audience comes to the exhibition they not only learn about the complexities of some of the most pressing issues in the world, but they also support the work of visual journalists worldwide, who have to do their job in increasingly dficult and dangerous circumstances.The free exhibition will be displayed in the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Main Hall from until August .

title: alexander-riding-high-national-dressage-success
story: ONE member of the Tweeddale Rideability Group is rightly sitting a little higher in the saddle after winning a third-place at the coveted Riding for the Disabled AssociationsNational Championships.Alexander Clark had already won the regional dressage competition in May to qualy for the Championships in Gloucestershire.It was a near perfect performance aboard Gleann Albainn in the walk-only, unled dressage class to claim the victory at the Scottish National Equestrian Centre.But problems with transporting the Tweeddale groups Clydesdale cob down to Hartpury College for the national championships put Alexanders finals place in doubt.Thankfully, staff at the Ravelrig Group offered the Peeblesshire rider use of one of their horses.And, competing against riders from across the UK, Alexander and new mount Thumper came third.Katherine Carson from the Tweeddale Rideability Group told us: "A very generous offer from the Ravelrig Group of a ride on their lovely big, grey horse, Thumper, allowed Alexander to enter and he and his family travelled to Gloucester to experience a weekend at this truly amazing and inspiring event."The Championships showcase all the RDA disciplines - dressage, show jumping, carriage driving, vaulting, showing, the countryside challenge and, for the first time this year, endurance."There are also competitions for musical rides recorded on video, and arts  crafts."The event grows every year and is now the largest event of its kind in the world. There are hundreds of competitors of all abilities, supported by their families and many volunteers and it is often a stepping stone for riders going on to join the Paralympic team."Alexander was placed third in his dressage class, competing against riders from across the UK, and he also won a distinction in the Horse Care test."Alexander was supported throughout the Championships by his parents, Carol and Gordon.And they are delighted with the benefits as well as rosettes horse riding has brought for their son.Carol said: "Alexander has been riding with the Tweeddale Rideability Group since primary school."Riding has improved Alexanders core strength resulting in signicant improvements in his balance, posture and muscle strength, particularly in his legs."RDA has helped improve Alexanders confidence and self esteem."He has been encouraged to attend the RDA Borders Quiz, as part of teams from Tweeddale. He has also been supported when taking part in dressage competitions which has resulted in successes such as his first place in his class at the Regional Dressage Competition and third place in the RDA National Championships."As well as saddling up with the Tweeddale Rideability Group, Alexander volunteers every Saturday morning to prepare all of the horses ahead of sessions.Dad Gordon added: "RDA is a big part of Alexanders le but this could not happen without the incredible team of coaches and volunteers who give up a huge amount of their time to support all riders."Alexander wasnt the only Tweeddale rider tofrom Gloucestershire with a rosette.Oscar Lowther also won a third in class at the national championships in the Arts  Crafts section for his sculpture of a horse and rider.

title: power-point-galashiels-sewage-plant
story: BOSSES at Scottish Water are so proud of their Gala waste treatment works that they want to tell the world.And they made a start last week by erecting signs around on the gates of the riverside plant as well as next to popular pathways.The bright blue signs highlight the energy savings generated at the pioneering site.As well as brief explanation on how the site uses a technique called Combined Heat and Power the signs also describe how the works are now one of Scottish waters most self-sufficient energy sites, generating enough power for  homes.Site operator Brian Reavely, who has worked at the Gala plant for the past  years told us: "Most people in Galashiels know this site is here and what it does, but not many know just how energy efficient it is."We wanted to do something to let people living here and visiting the area about how green this place ndash which provides a vital service to the town and surrounding area ndash is.ldquoI had made paper made signs reminding us of how self-sufficient the site is and put them in ious places such like our canteen and noticeboard. I thought it would be a good idea to let people in the area know about our achievements and it was decided a plaque highlighting how energy efficient we are was a good way to do this.ldquoMany people use the walkways around here and I hope they will be interested in learning about how green we are. It is a great achievement and makes me proud to work here.More than  of Scottish Waterrsquos water and wastewater treatment works are either self-sufficient or partly sufficient in their power requirements, leading to lower operating costs and a more sustainable business.Since the Galashiels site started using Combined Heat and Power four years ago the amount of energy it imports has dropped by two thirds.The Galashiels site treats sludge from most parts of the Borders including Eyemouth in the east to Newcastleton in the west.

title: thousands-littered-bottles-set-vanish-borders-thanks-20p-recycling-scheme
story: People in the Borders can wave goodbye to as many as , plastic bottles next year thanks to new Deposit Return scheme.Thousands of plastic bottles and cans could be kept out of the environment in the Scottish Borders due to a pioneering new lsquomoney backrsquo system that will encourage people to recycle more and litter less.Figures published by environmental body Zero Waste Scotland, revealed the scale of plastic bottle dumping in the Scottish Borders.And how it will be reduced by Scotlandrsquos forthcoming depositscheme.Every year, people in the Scottish Borders go through . million plastic bottles.And an estimated , of those plastic bottles are littered around the Borders each year.Under the new scheme, shoppers will pay a p deposit when buying drinks purchased in single-use plastic, glass bottles, and aluminium or steel cans.People will then get their money back when theytheir empty container for recycling.That p is hoped to give people an extra incentive to recycle their empty bottles and cans, and make people think twice about dropping them.With a p incentive not to throw away your empties, Zero Waste Scotland anticipates a  per cent reduction in litter for the materials mentioned.This would mean nearly , fewer plastic bottles dropped in Scottish Borders each year.With plastic bottles only one of the materials included in the scheme, the overall impact on litter is expected to be even higher.Jill Farrell, Chief Operating Officer, Zero Waste Scotland said: ldquoOur new figures reveal how Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme could visibly slash the number of littered plastic bottles in the Borders.ldquoWe all hate seeing empty bottles and cans littering our streets, green spaces and beaches.ldquoAnd the great thing about Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme is it will give people a p incentive to do the right thing with their empty bottles, take them back for recycling, rather than risk them ending up on our streets or in our rivers.ldquoLitter isnrsquot just an eyesore ndash it also pollutes our environment and seas.ldquoAnd for every bottle littered, more plastic must be created, generating more planet-damaging emissions.ldquoWhen you take back your empty bottles to be recycled, yoursquoll not just be getting your p back, yoursquoll be doing your bit in the fight against the climate emergency.All types of drinks in containers between  ml and  litres in size are included in the Deposit Return scheme.Across Scotland, wherever people can buy a drink in a container made from one of these materials, they will also be able toit to reclaim the deposit.Online retailers will also be included in the scheme, ensuring itrsquos accessible to people that are dependent on online delivery.The Scottish Government is expected to introduce legislation to enable the scheme later this year.For more information about Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme, visit www.deposit.scot

title: tv-casting-opportunity-comes-galashiels
story: AWARD-WINNING independent TV company to start filming for a brand-new series, in Galashiels this month.From the makers of GPrsquos Behind Closed Doors and The Gypsies Next Door, Knickerbockerglory are now casting for a new primetime documentary series, looking at building works and the detrimental impact this can have on either the builders or those living in the neighbouring areas.Brandon Rose, Casting Researcher, told us he wanted to ldquospread the word of this great opportunity for Galashiels residents.He added: ldquoThe documentary will look to explore behind the headlines, discussing the topics of dust, noise and how this impacts peoples daily lives.ldquoIn addition, the programme will ask those affectedthey feel as a result of the building works their neighbours are feeling under pressure  Or is it causing tension on the street ldquoWe will also be exploring the other view point and we will be championing builders who are following all of the regulations and are coming up against neighbours constantly obstructing them at every turn.If you would like to take part in the programme, contact Knickerbockerglory by calling    or emailing shannon@knickerbockerglory.tv.For more information visit http:www.knickerbockerglory.tv factual

title: pets-factor-2019---win-300-plus-great-goody-bags
story: Nows your chance to see all of the entries in our fantastic new-look Pets Factor competition!Proud pet owners from across the Scottish Borders have sent in pictures of their perfect pets and in next weeks paperwersquore featuring all of those who are competing for the title and the pound cash prize.And this year weve joined forces with our friends at Border Vets to make our competition bigger and better than ever.The vets practice, which has branches at Innerleithen, Galashiels and Selkirk, have given us goody bags worth pound for the winner, pound for the runner-up and pound for the third placed pet.The aim at Border Vets is to help your pet live a long, happy and healthy le.Visit bordervets for details of their Pet Health Plans, dental staging and x-rays, eVets  hour pet care and Nurse clinics.The winner of this years Pets Factor will be decided by you, our readers.Youll find the first voting token on the inside back page of next weeks paper, so make sure you get voting now.Well print tokens every week and our first round of voting will last until noon on August , . Remember you can enclose multiple tokens in one envelope to save on postage!Well then count all the votes to whittle down the entries to our top  which well publish on August .Then youll have until noon on September  to get your votes in to keep your favourite pet in the running as well then cut it down to our top  which well publish on September .Keep voting until noon on September  to ensure your top choice makes it into the top  which well publish on October .Yoursquoll then have until noon on October  to vote for your winner and wersquoll announce details shortly after then.Dont miss out ndash see next weeks paper for details.

title: earl-39-s-rare-unseen-photographs-go-display
story: AN exhibition charting the photography of a former Earl is being developed at Thirlestane Castle.The new photography exhibition features works by the th Earl of Lauderdale which have never been on public display before.The exhibition will include some of the early bromoil printing techniques used by Frederick Colin Maitland at the turn of the last century, as well as pre-Photoshop examples of edited images and how these were achieved.As well as never before seen images, there will also be a selection of his more vernacular work to give audiences a taster of the th Earlrsquos broad range of photographic skills.Entitled lsquoTheoretical Sharpnessrsquo, the exhibition has been created by local photography artist Sam Cornwell.He was tasked with beginning the curation, study and preservation of the th Earlrsquos extensive archive that dates from the late th century.During his work he was fascinated by a series of images of clouds which the th Earl used as a library for the editing of his work.The title of the exhibition comes from one of many columns Maitland wrote for a national newspaper in the s.A phrase he coined that epitomises his work he considered that photographs in total sharpness were not artistic at all, and this is reflected in his award winning work.Edward Maitland-Carew said: ldquoI am so thrilled to be able to share my great, great grandfatherrsquos amazing work with a wider audience."The th Earl of Lauderdale was extremely talented and very much at the forefront of the photography world winning many awards for his work."Sam Cornwell has done a fantastic job at examining these unique pieces and preparing them for display.The exhibition will be open from am daily between Monday and Thursday, August  and  and is included in the normal admission ticket to the castle.

title: kalzie-takes-flutter-new-butterfly-house
story: IF you havent been for a while, its worth a flutter on atrip to Kailzie Gardens this month.The picturesque estate outside Peebles had been attracting visitors for years to savour its stunning gardens, view the regions osprey nests, dine in the cafe, or enjoy the range of family attractions.But staff at Kailzie have hatched a plan for making the historic gardens even more of desirable - butterflies.Dozens of the most colourful species have recently hatched in the conservatory.And the fluttering creatures are already proving popular with guests of al ages.Lady Buchan-Hepburn from Kailzie Gardens told us: "We have always been butterfly friendly at Kailzie Gardens with the types of plants we have but this year we decided to take it a stage further."We have hatched our own butterflies in the conservatory, which is now our butterfly house, and it is proving highly successful."We now have a fascinating and extremely beautul collection - there must have been around  of them flying around when I was last in."The new butterfly house is open throughout the summer.Kailzie Gardens, which are situated just off the B between Peebles and Cardrona, is open between am and .pm every day.

title: job-losses-empty-units-arcadia-group-pulls-galashiels
story: UP to  jobs could be lost in the next couple of months with the planned closure of two clothing stores in Galashiels.It is understood that the shutters will come down on both Burtons and Dorothy Perkins in October.Although nobody at the Arcadia Group headquarters would discuss or confirm the reports, staff have been notied and closing down posters were placed in the windows last week.As well as the loss of jobs, the store closures will add to the number of empty units on one of Galas main shopping streets.Councillor Euan Jardine told us: "I am extremely disappointed that these stores are closing."They have been an asset to Galashiels and the region for many years and I have written to Arcadia to vent my frustration and also ask about the future of the staff that are employed in store."Unfortunately, peoplersquos shopping habits are changing."The fact you can now in certain places get same day delivery from stores like Amazon, really shows how hard it is for retail stores to survive on the modern day high street."There are already close to a dozen empty shops on the main street leading up to the under-construction Tapestry Visitor Centre.Councillor Jardine hopes ongoing talks with retail groups will attract new businesses to Galashiels ahead of the grand opening.He added: "The council have been contacting national retail providers in an effort to occupy empty stores on Channel Street."They have faced a few stumbling blocks to retailers commitment to expansion which include ious political matters that dominate the headlines both in Scotland and Britain as a whole."However, with the Tapestry opening soon, the footfall in the area will increase and this is one of the main selling points we are using when trying to entice retailers."I also think discussions with the people responsible for letting these properties has to be explored."I would ask for any business to have faith in the town, which is going through a phase of regeneration and really emphasise the point that Galashiels is open for business and a great place for your business to succeed."Sir Philip Greens Arcadia Group announced in May that it was closing  stores across the UK with the loss of around  jobs.But only Glasgow and Aberdeen were the Scottish outlets to appear on the hit list.But further financial problems for the international retail group in June led to a rescue plan being unveiled to shareholders involving , job losses and shutting a further  stores.The Arcadia Group, whose brands also include Topshop, Miss Selfridge and Evans, have refused to discuss this latest tranch of closures.But chief executive Ian Grabiner was more talkative in May when announcing the initial job losses.He said: "Against a backdrop of challenging retail headwinds, changing consumer habits and ever-increasing online competition, we have seriously considered all possible strategic options tothe Group to a stable financial .ldquoThis has been a tough but necessary decision for the business."

title: brexit-secretary-let-barnier-renegotiate-no-deal-coming-tracks

title: galashiels-set-scottish-opera-39-s-highlights
story: GALASHIELS has been included in Scottish Operarsquos hugely popular Opera Highlights tour.From next month four singers and a pianist will travel theand breadth of the country to perform.And on Tuesday, October  they arrive at the Volunteer Hall.The setting for director Roxana Hainesrsquo production of Opera Highlights is a beautul garden party, and features a playlist of operatic classics and must-hear rarities, curated by Scottish Operarsquos Head of Music Derek Clark.Highlights include Delibesrsquo Flower Duet, Vaughan Williamsrsquo Blue Larkspur in a Garden and many more from the likes of Mozart, Lehaacuter and Scottish Opera Composer in Residence, Samuel Bordoli.Pianist Music Director Ian Shaw is joined by Scottish Opera emerging soprano Charlie Drummond mezzo-soprano Martha Jones tenor Alex Bevan and baritone Mark Nathan.Roxana Haines, who is directing Scottish Operarsquos Fox-tot! at Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer, said: "This years Opera Highlights cast cordially invite you to a party on your doorstep, set throughout luscious gardens and magical flora and fauna of Opera."The stage has been set, decorations unpacked and the guests have all arrived but, the only problem is, no one quite knows who or why were celebrating."As the evening progresses, the connections between our characters unravel through music from the likes of Handel, Donizetti and Mozart, and lighter pieces from Gilbert  Sullivan and Vaughan Williams as well as a new work by Samuel Bordoli."Prepare for charm, magic and love in all its operatic forms."The same show s in Spring , with a dferent cast: soprano Zoe Drummond mezzo-soprano Jade Moffat tenor Andrew Irwin and baritone Arthur Bruce, with Peebles included in next years dates.Scottish Operarsquos general director Alex Reedijk told us: "I am delighted that Scottish Opera will be touring what promises to be another sensational Opera Highlights to  venues across Scotland in the Autumn and Spring."This longstanding and much acclaimed commitment by the Company to presenting work across Scotland is part of what makes us Scottish Opera, and is welcomed by our far-flung audiences as a lovely operatic tonic!"Opera Highlights also serves to introduce young singers to our audiences, and greatly assists their development as artists alongside presenting the joys of opera and singing to our widely spread audience.rsquo"This Opera Highlights tour is supported by The Friends of Scottish Opera, JTH Charitable Trust and The Scottish Opera Endowment Trust.

title: earlston-welcomes-brand-new-burns-mozart-inspired-opera
story: BURNS night is back, and this time with an operatic twist.Touring this autumn is Amadeus  The Bard: th Century Cosmic Brothers, a brand-new show from Scottish Opera.Debuting at Earlston High School, Amadeus  The Bard celebrates the lives of two much-loved men, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Robert Burns.Through storytelling and song, Scottish Opera will honour the many and sometimes surprising similarities between them.Created and directed by Mary McCluskey the former Artistic Director of Scottish Youth Theatre, the show is sure to entertain.Opening night is in Earlston High School after which the production tours to schools in six other Scottish towns, as well as the National Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh.And the Scottish Opera Production Studios in Glasgow.Set in Poosie Nansiersquos Inn, a favourite haunt of Burns, the cast blend traditional folk songs with some of Mozartrsquos most popular work.From Tam OrsquoShanter and The Magic Flute, to A Red, Red Rose and The Marriage of Figaro, audiences are sure to enjoy the night in celebration of the beloved musical geniuses.Jane Davidson, Scottish Operarsquos Director of Outreach and Education said: ldquoAmadeus  The Bard affords us some fascinating glimpses into thelives of Robert Burns and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.ldquoBoth are cultural icons of the eighteenth century whose musical and literary lsquovoicesrsquo have inspired people through the generations down to the present day.Karen MacIver is the Music Director and pianist on this dramatic show, which features a talented cast including Arthur Bruce, The Robertson Trust Scottish Opera Emerging Artist .Alongside Arthur will be actor Andy Clark, soprano Stephanie Stanway and violinist Shannon Stevenson.They are joined by an ensemble of four singers from Scottish Opera Young Company: Cara Blaikie, Ross Fettes, James McIntyre and Erin Spence.Director Mary McCluskey said: ldquoIt is our intention for our merry band of talented performers, singers, actors and musicians to give you an insight into the work of Mozart and Burns.ldquoWe hope to entertain and inform you, in order that you will leave knowing more than you did when you came along to see the production, and that we will have whetted your appetite for the work of these two talented men.Jane added: ldquoThe warmest of welcomes is extended to everyone to join our dynamic young company of performers around the fireside in Poosie Nansiersquos hostelry for an hour of songs, ensembles, arias and poetry.The performance takes place in Earlston High School on Monday, September  at pm.For more information visit https:www.scottishopera.org.uk amadeus

title: combat-loneliness-chatty-cafe
story: HAWICK is being introduced to a new scheme to help battle loneliness in the community.Now, people who fancy a chat with someone new while enjoying a cuppa, can do so at Heart of Hawick.Introduced to the area by Live Borders, the Chatty Cafeacute scheme, is also spreading across the UK.There are now over  cafes taking part and anyone can join in.If yoursquore on your own, in a couple, or with a friend or child, look for the sign on the table, and take a seat.Alexandra Hoskyn, Founder of The Chatty Cafeacute scheme, said: ldquoThe scheme was created on a wet and windy day when I was in a supermarket cafeacute with my four-month-old son.ldquoHe wasnrsquot great company and I was fed up. I looked around the cafeacute and saw an elderly lady who looked just as down as me and, on another table, sat a young guy with additional needs and his support worker, both looking like they had run out of conversation.ldquoI started to think about the positive impact we could have had on each otherwe had sat together.ldquoI know from experience that when you are feeling lonely, a short conversation with another human can really brighten your day and I realised that you can be out of the house all day yet have no interaction with another person.And so, Alexandra came up with the idea of a Chatter  Natter table where customers can sitthey would like to talk to other customers.A lsquoChatter  Natterrsquo table is a space for people to talk whether it is for five minutes or longer.The scheme encourages simple interactions to combat loneliness: a chat may have a big impact on someonersquos day.Sophy Delavigne, Operations Manager at Heart of Hawick said: ldquoAs soon as we heard about the Chatty Cafeacute scheme, Heart of Hawick wanted to join.ldquoWe think itrsquos a fantastic idea and already have the support of our regular customers.ldquoAs a charity, every penny spent across Live Borders centres and venues is invested back into the community to help make lives healthier, happier and stronger, which this scheme definitely accomplishes.For further information visit: www.heartofhawick and thechattycafescheme blog

story: Reporter Aimee Spence took to the streets recently to find out what the people of Campbeltown think about the BBC#s plan to scrap free TV licences for those aged  and over.The results were hardly surprising # near universal condemnation from those interviewed. title: letter creating dementia friendly communities in kintyre
story: We are organising some information events to let people know what we are planning in their area for older people in general and to gather the thoughts of the local communities.They will take place on the following dates: Tuesday August , Tarbert Templers Hall, -pm Monday August , Clachan Village Hall, am to pm Tuesday September , Tayinloan Village Hall, am to noon Friday September , Carradale Village Hall, noon to pm.Dementia touches so many in Kintyre and we are keen to talk to as many people as possible about real lived experiences locally. If you cannot attend the events please contact me, Sarah, Shopper-Aide#s dementia project development coordinator.We would be very grateful to anyone who is willing to share their knowledge of living in Kintyre with dementia.Furthermore Shopper-Aide Ltd will be promoting the Dementia Friends programme which is run by Alzheimer Scotland. Any group, business or inidual who is interested in participating in becoming #dementia aware#, please email sarah@shopper-aide.org.uk or call   for more information.Shopper-Aide will be launching its new logo and window sticker to indicate that there are iniduals in the premises who have undergone the ‘Dementia Friends’ awareness programme and these iniduals can be recognised by the forget-me-not badge they wear.Our activities and groups are aimed at anyone over  and are open to all.This work is supported with funding from the Le Changes Trust, which is funded by The National Lottery Community Fund.Sarah McFadzean,

title: letter islay in darkness
story: We are concerned that the installation of new streetlights, mounted on metal lamp-posts, could detract from the appearance of some roads in Port Charlotte, which is a designated conservation area. The new lights would replace wall-mounted lights and could, residents fear, make a signicant impact on the character of the area.A number of residents have been in contact about this matter as they fear that the introduction of these lights, which are really more suited to an urban setting, are inappropriate to their village.I think it is incumbent on the council to show some regard to their concerns as local people are, rightly, proud of their architectural heritage and do not want to see it compromised by the insensitive implementation of a policy which is not appropriate for their community.I would urge them to look again at this issue.Donald Cameron MSP,

title: the greatest show in a decade raises thousands for charity
story: #The greatest show that Campbeltown has seen for a decade,# is how one audience member described a musical fundraising extravaganza, which an initial count suggests made about £, for charity.Extra seats had to be borrowed from Campbeltown Town Hall so the Victoria Hall could be filled to capacity for Campbeltown Takes On The Greatest Showman, organised by fundraising supremo Cheryl Brown.Cheryl dedicated the evening # which was in aid of Breast Cancer Now and the Mairi Semple Cancer Fund, with an amount also donated to a local woman suffering from breast cancer # to everyone who has suffered or is suffering from the illness.A troupe of local artists, as well as a visiting performer, sang and danced to several of the  hit musical#s most popular songs, including The Greatest Show, This Is Me, Come Alive, Re-write the Stars, From Now On.Performers included singers Wendy Beasley, Gary Anderson, Erin Ferguson, Hope Strang, Ruairidh Wallace, Lindsey Cairns and local choir The Upbeats, dancer Morgan Irwin and dance groups Dance Legacy and Dance Collective, and musical theatre students Hannah Black, from Kintyre, and visitor Ally Kennard.As well as Cheryl, the crew working hard behind the scenes included Jamie Girvan, Randall Robertson, Mandy Robertson, Claire Cairney, Paula McLean and Bobby Cairns.There was also a raffle, for which many ied prizes were donated by local businesses and iniduals, and a lucky squares competition, with the winner donating the prize money back into the evening#s fund.Speaking after the production#s finale, Cheryl revealed that MC Helen Gilchrist, who kept the evening running smoothly with her usual good-spirited humour, was one of her inspirations for organising it.Cheryl said: #Over  years ago, my friend and I sang on this very stage to the one and only Spice Girls. Helen, my mum [Andrea], Davie Brodie and many others put a show together called Kids Stars In Their Eyes, which was a great success and always stayed with me, and gave me the inspiration for the show.#This is not Cheryl#s first fundraiser # in the past few years she has organised a s and s-themed night in aid of Prostate Cancer UK, a gig by Stone Roses tribute act Resurrection in aid of Shopper-Aide, The Hub and Elderberries, and a #rave# for toddlers in aid of Youth Impact.Speaking to the Courier this week, Cheryl said: #I love organising events that I would like to go to, so that makes it easier, and also I love music, so that helps.#Raising money is a bonus and there is always someone who needs it more than me. I#ve learned that you get out what you put in from the universe, whether it#s positive or negative.#Of Saturday#s show, for which planning started in February, she said: #The talent and generosity in this town is unbelievable. I want to say thank you to the town hall for supplying us with the extra seats to enable us to sell extra tickets, and thank you to everyone for their donations and raffle prizes, and to all the performers for taking part.#Gary Anderson as The Greatest Showman#s PT Barnum, supported by The Upbeats. title: a little light chamber music
story: The programme was based on th century compositions and featured works of three of the great romantic composers. The opening piece by Saint-Saëns was the perfect choice for the more intimate style of the smaller-scale orchestra. The central work was Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto in which the orchestra’s Director, Benjamin Marquise Gilmore, played the solo part and gave a stunning performance.At the end of the first movement, the audience were treated to an outstanding display of professionalism from the orchestra, when one of the strings on the soloist’s violin snapped, but then watched the smoothest of transitions as the player at the first desk immediately handed the soloist her own violin and the music continued uninterrupted while another player repaired the broken string.The concert finished with Beethoven’s nd Symphony and it was especially good to hear the use of natural trumpets and horns in this early but most attractive work. Also singled out for praise was the woodwind section and knitting all the performances together was the New Zealand conductor, Holly Mathieson. A most enjoyable evening.                                                                                                                          David McEwanHolly Mathieson conducts the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. title: campbeltown courier letters week 31
story: Sir,I wish to thank all the people of Campbeltown and especially the members of Yes Kintyre for the wonderful hospitality they gave us independence marchers on Saturday. I#ve been on many a demonstration in my time and this was one of the best.Rolling off the ferry on the Friday evening we were welcomed by a guard-of-honour standing along the pier waving saltires.The townsfolk turned out in droves to welcome us, waving saltires from windows and even stringing saltire bunting across the street at fourth-storey level. I had the romantic impression that the good folk of Campbeltown had been following the ious pro-independence rallies as they worked their way around the geography of Scotland and had just been waiting for their own town#s turn!The sun stayed out for us right until pm. Then the rain suddenly came down and we took down our Pensioners for Independence stall.  That evening Yes Kintyre put on a special party for us all with local musicians in the Argyll Arms Hotel.On Sunday some of us stayed on and explored your beautul peninsula. As the ferry pulled away that evening members of Yes Kintyre stood along the harbour wall holding up saltires to bid us farewell.Thank you all again for a memorable experience.Yours,Mary McCabe,Glasgow.Sir,It was my great privilege to attend yet another Open at Royal Portrush and to witness  year-old Oban golfer Robert MacIntyre finish tied sixth in his very first Major Championship.It was a wonderful performance, and confirmation, of the talent and the temperament we, the journalists, felt sure that he had.  He is now a Euro millionaire, but he remains an open, helpful and cheerful lad with both feet firmly planted on the ground, thanks to a great family and a strong desire to remain in his home town.I was at Glencruitten for the first time in June and soon discovered why Robert wants to go back there on a regular basis after weeks on tour.  It#s a terric club, no airs and graces.  They are very proud of Robert, and rightly so, but I very much doubtthey would allow him to lose his down-to-earth approach to international recognition.Yours,Jock MacVicar, Southend-born Scottishgolf correspondent and long-time Dunaverty member. Sir,Through the columns of your newspaper, may I express my grateful thanks to all the businesses, organisations, and iniduals, who donated to our fundraising, allowing the dancers to compete in the United States Highland Dancing Championships held recently in Las Vegas.We had a very successful trip, placing in both the Highland and choreography events. It’s installed in the dancers they are there to represent Campbeltown and the Dance School rather than any inidual, and hearing the town name announced at the presentation of trophies to our four trophy winners was a very proud moment indeed. The dancers fought every inch of the way to put our small town on the map.Our thanks once again to the following: MACC, Tangy Wind Farm, West Kintyre Wind Farm, Killieguer Caravan Park, DM Fabrication, Glenside Tractors, Howdens, Kintyre Youth Fund, McFadyens Contractors, Tesco Bags of Help, Jim Martin Supplies, Southend Parish Church, Peter McKerral  Son, C’town Co-Op, C’town Running Club, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Firemans Club, C’town Motor Co, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Loyal, C’town Common Good Fund, C’town Inner Wheel, C’town Community Council, Paul Grumoli, Mr and Mrs Brown, Mr and Mrs Russell, and Laura and Jake, Tesco Staff.Yours,James McCorkindale,McCorkindale School of Dancing.Sir,On Monday evening, July , five sacks of tin cans had been placed in the clear glass bin in Tesco#s car park. Some sort of gathering must have taken place over the weekend. You cannot run a countryyou can#t distinguish between a glass bottle and a tin can.At least something sensible is going to be done about the Rest and Be Thankful road. It was acceptable to try to prevent the hillside from being washed onto the roadway. It has been obvious for several months,not years, that that was not possible.At last someone has seen thata wide trench is dug between the hillside and the road, the hillside can still be washed down but will not reach the roadway.Yours,James W Mackay,Campbeltown.

title: campbeltown rallies to independence march
story: The independence march through Campbeltown on Saturday was a huge success and put a real zest for le back into the town which has been too long forgotten.That was the view of organiser Manny Singh who despite his apparent sacking from the All Under One Banner organisation was very much still in charge at the Campbeltown march.Afterwards he said: #It was a huge success for Campbeltown and the biggest demonstration for decades. There was a lot of spirit and a feeling that a number of towns in Scotland which have been forgotten, like Campbeltown, will not be left behind after independence.#He put the turnout at more than , and added: #The fact that the march extended theof Longrow gives a fair indication of the numbers who were there.He also told the Courier this week that he remained the #legal indentity# of the All Under One Banner group, despite a bitter public row among the hierarchy which looks like splitting the group in two.It was the biggest rally held in the town in recent years with marchers coming from as far afield as Aberdeen and Alloa and as well as Oban, Glasgow and Islay, with many travelling on the weekend ferry from Ardrossan.#It really exceeded expectations and made a big splash in the town, Ron Wilson of Yes Kintyre told The National.#There was a real buzz as people came early and most of the hotels were booked up. The pubs and cafes were busy so it was good for local businesses. Campbeltown is a Yes town and it was brilliant to have all these people come here. Local people were coming off the pavements and joining the procession so it created a good, positive vibe.Pro-Unionists opponents held their own counter demonstation. However, the march went off without any incident and there were no arrests, with only one warning which was drug related.A spit of rain earlier in the day failed to develop into poor weather as the marchers would round the town to hear speakers and listen to musicians at the rally at Kinloch Green.Mr Wilson said he was particuarly pleased at the turnout as there had been some confusion over whether the march would go ahead due to internal sions within the hierachcy of All Under One Banner, which has organised independence marches across the country.Following Mr Singh#s sacking, founder Neil Mackay resigned from his position on its national executive pending an internal investigation.Pro-UK Unionist group A Force For Good met the march on the shore front and say they filmed and counted the marchers, as they have at previous events, and afterwards claimed the turnout was just .Director, Alistair McConnachie, said: #All Under One Banner is basically the marching wing of the SNP. AUOB, and SNP MPs and MSPs, lie about the numbers which attend their marches, sometimes up to  or  times.#Unfortunately, they are not challenged by the Scottish media. The good news is that A Force For Good has a presence at every AUOB march. We bear witness to the huge value of the United Kingdom.  Our #Thin Red Line# stands for everyone who likes being British, who likes the UK, and who wants us to stay together.#A group from Barrowfield at the Campbeltown cross ahead of the march. title: cricketer liam chases his world cup dream
story: A young cricket star with Campbeltown connections has been starring for Scotland under-s in the team’s quest to qualy for the World Cup.Teenager Liam Naylor # who lives in Liverpool but whose mother Marie Naylor is originally from Campbeltown # and his compatriots have been in The Netherlands for a week-long qualying round that has seen them take on the host country, as well as Ireland, France, Jersey and Denmark.And while Liam, , began playing the game in Merseyside with Alder Cricket Club at the age of , rising through the ranks to turn out for the club’s first team as a seam bowler at , he has since earned a two-year scholarship to play cricket and study sport at the Wellington School, in Taunton, Somerset, after being scouted by Steffan Jones, a household name in English county cricket as a fast bowler, and as a coach in Indian cricket for Rajasthan Royals.As an avid Liverpool FC fan, Liam regularly attends matches at Anfield with his mum, sister Hannah and football-mad dad Phil Naylor, but Marie explained how Liam’s love for batting sports also runs in the family.Marie said: ‘I spent many happy summers playing rounders with my friends on Meadows Field growing up, and coming back to Campbeltown Liam would always want to play cricket # not rounders, but cricket # on that same field.‘Liam has already represented Scotland under-s, so to go away with the under-s is another really exciting opportunity. We’re really proud of him.’Earlier in the week, Liam and teammates defeated both the Netherlands and Jersey, with all-rounder Liam scoring a superb  runs against the Channel Islanders. The group winners will qualy for next year’s ICC Under- Cricket World Cup in South Africa. Full details can be found at icc-cricketLiam is the grandson of Douglas McKerral, and the late Willie McKerral, of Meadows Avenue, Campbeltown.Liam Naylor batting at the stumps. title: thought for the week week 31
story: Imagine. Imagine a world where no one was hungry, a world where no one was homeless, a world where the most powerless were given a voice.Imagine. Imagine a world like that.John Lennon penned these words of hope and inspiration when he wrote his famous song, #Imagine#.It is worth looking again at his words:#Imagine there#s no countriesImagine all the peopleYou, you may say I#m a dreamerImagine no possessionsImagine…#Could we, in reality, imagine such a world As the problems of our country and our world grow deeper, we need some dreamers.We need a voice of hope, not of hate.We need a voice of truth, not of turbulence.We need a voice that will inspire with values of integrity and honour.We need a voice to show us the way in these disturbing times.We need a voice we can trust.There are many voices shouting at us these days, there are many voices that do not call for peace at this time.In all the shouting and the arguing and the anger, let us take time to find a quiet place and listen.Let us listen for that whisper, the voice of truth, the one that comes from the Prince of Peace himself.Imagine.

title: work-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall-set-start-soon
story: The much-anticipated hall has been in the pipeline for several years and plans for the expansion were lodged with East Lothian Council more than two years ago.The local authority says that contracts for the work are expected to be awarded this month, with contractors expected to start on site in September.The new hall will allow the centre to offer more activities and a wider range of sports than ever before, including basketball, badminton, tennis and football.It will also allow centre regulars such as East Lothian Gymnastics Association the chance to train with a proper run-up to their apparatus.The new hall, which will be an extension to the main building, will measure  metres by  metres and also includes storage areas.There will be a new lobby created to link the hall to the cafe area of the main centre building and it will provide capacity for more classes to be held in the centre.It is being built to the west of the current building, with plans to move the childrenrsquos play area, re-siting it beside the new hall, in an area which will be better positioned for parents to keep an eye on youngsters.A report to the council revealed there had been a delay on the work as the ldquotechnical specs were revised to bring it within budget.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe main elements of our investment at Port Seton Community Centre to provide a new sports hall with provision for gymnastics remains unchanged.ldquoIn order to secure best value and deliver the project within budget, we have revisited the technical specications for the project.ldquoWe now anticipate awarding the contract for works in late July with contractors starting on site in September.ldquoWe are working with the centrersquos management group to keep them involved as the project progresses.

title: prestonpans-schools-pupils-aiming-get-involved-community
story: St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School sent P representatives Olivia Lees, Ciaran Kelly, Fraser Graham, and Daniel McCabe, all , to speak to Prestonpans Community Council about their work and the potential involvement of much younger participants.The school was recently successful in achieving its UNICEF Rights Respecting School gold award, which means that it had proved that it incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child into the school through both teaching and actions.It now aims to take this further and bring this ethos into the surrounding community.The children were given the chance of addressing the meeting, which included ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and Neil Gilbert, to ask questions and discuss the best ways to engage young people with what is going on in the community and to ensure their input is noted.The children asked about the plans for the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station and whether more activities for young people such as Rainbows and Scouts could be introduced to the areaWhen addressing the councillors and community councillors, Daniel, a house captain from St Gabrielrsquos, said: ldquoItrsquos important for us at this stage to know what our future is going to hold, and to try and make a dference when and where we can.ldquoTo be involved in the community council in some way would be fantastic, as it would give us comfort to know that the community is being taken care of, as well as what decisions were being made that might affect us.It was decided that the community council would send the agenda for each meeting to the school a few days before the meeting took place so that the children could see it and comment on any issues being raised.The community council said in a statement: ldquoWe would like to thank the four fantastic pupils from St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who attended the community council.ldquoIt was so refreshing to have such polite and knowledgeable young people along to one of our meetings to share their opinions and views on our agenda topics and ask the questions they feel most relevant to their lives.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them along to future meetings and collaborating with them on the issues that affect all of us living in Prestonpans.

title: music-fan-kevin-proves-39-s-popmaster
story: Kevin OrsquoDonnell stole the show when he appeared on PopMaster on BBC Radio .A score of  out of  was enough to win the quiz on Ken Brucersquos show.Kevin, who runs his own joinery and garden business, told the Courier: ldquoIt was something that I always wanted to do.ldquoI am right into my music and PopMaster is probably the premier music quiz in Britain.The -year-oldrsquos opponent managed a score of , with Kevin declared the winner and receiving the prize of a digital speaker in the shape of an old-style microphone.The prize has taken pride of place in Kevinrsquos West Barns home, with dozens of people getting in touch with him to offer their congratulations since the show was broadcast.He said: ldquoI met Bruce Springsteen in  in Newcastle and I think this is not quite up there with that but it is not far off.The popular radio quiz has been running for a number of years and each contestant is asked  questions based on popular music from the s through to the present day.He said: ldquoI have listened to Ken Bruce for a good  or  years and the last couple of years I have tried to get on the show.ldquoMy kids have always been saying to me to go.ldquoMy son, Conor, is the lead guitarist in The Tesla Coils and we are always discussing and talking about music.The music fan, who spoke to the Courier as he was en route to see American rock legends Kiss perform at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, played down his achievement and said the questions simply fell in his favour.ldquoYou can get a possible  points thatrsquos the maximum you can score, said Kevin. ldquoThat is based on  questions and it is just general music knowledge. It just depends onit is for you.ldquoAll my stuff is s and s music andthe questions had been about the year  I would have got five out of !ldquoIt is really luck andthe questions are for you ndash it just happened that the questions were from my era.

title: connor-farrell-barber-stars-scottish-open-golf-renaissance-club
story: Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament at The Renaissance Club earlier this month, was among the professionals putting their feet up for a moment and getting a trim from Connor Farrell.The barber, who lives in Pencaitland, cut the hair of more than  golfers, caddies, management teams and sponsors.He said: ldquoYou see all these players on the television and then you get to have a good chat with them face to face. It was a good experience.ldquoWe were there and set up on the Monday and were Tuesday through Thursday, Friday cutting hair.ldquoWe were only supposed to be there on Tuesday and Wednesday but we got asked to stay on.ldquoWe reckon we did anywhere between  and  haircuts and it was all just complimentary. We did Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament, and Matt Wallace, who is ranked rd in the world.ldquoThey were all good guys. They are just normal people at the end of the day.ldquoWe talked about ious things ndash they wanted to know about good places to go eat in Edinburgh, ious local spots and seemed to like East Lothian and Edinburgh in general.Other golfers stepping into the hot seat included Lee Slattery, who finished tied for ninth at the competition, and West Lothianrsquos Stephen Gallacher.Former Ross High School pupil Connor, who is the owner and barber at Chaps Barber in Newcraighall, revealed that although the haircuts were complimentary, the golfers did offer generous tips and said: ldquoThey were pretty good ndash I cannot complain.Connor, who has been a barber for the last  months, got the chance through a family connection.His older sister Christy, , is dating North Berwick golfer Grant Forrest, who finished tied for rd at the event.Connor, , who plays golf at Longniddry Golf Club, was able to cheer Grant on.He said: ldquoThe European Tour got involved with Grantrsquos management company Bounce Sports.ldquoFrom there, they got the ball in motion and all the logistics of it.ldquoThese things take massive planning to get things done and it was quite a y process.ldquoIt took about two or three months to get it all finalised.

title: plea-save-former-dolphin-hotel-s-late
story: New le could be breathed into the former Dolphin Hotel, which included a bar and lounge on the ground floor.The bar closed in February  but the upstairs, which was used as a hotel, has not been in use for nearly  years.Developer The Dolphin InnLtd wants to ensure the building, on Dunbarrsquos Queenrsquos Road, has a future.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council for a hostel, complete with reception and cafe, on the ground floor.Under the proposals, the first floor would have four bedrooms, with three shower rooms and a family suite. The second floor would feature six bedrooms, with four bath or shower rooms, and the top floor acting as a managerrsquos flat.The developer has highlighted the poor state of the building and said that the first and second floors were ldquoseriously affected by dry rot and are unsafe.A ldquopriority of repairing the building and eradicating the advancing dry rot has been identied, with the developer keen to bring the building back into use ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, told the Courier she had previously seen inside the building and it was ldquoin a terrible state of repair.She said: ldquoAnybody that wants to come in and invest high-quality renovation in Dunbar is to be welcomed.ldquoIt is wonderful that the building, which is so prominent, is in line for a facelt.ldquoMy understanding is that the client group is going to be aimed at walkers and surfers and, again, that would be warmly welcomed.Attempts had previously been made to see the building re-open as a hotel. However, there was ldquono interest from potential developers.A design and access statement, which is included within the planning application, notes: ldquoItrsquos quite possible there has been no demand for this property to be retained as a hotel due to competition in the immediate vicinity, namely The Royal Mackintosh Hotel on Station Road and the Hillside Hotel on Queenrsquos Road.Two years ago, Dunbar Trout Farm Ltd, was given permission to transform the building. Those plans, approved in August , included the creation of two shops and four flats.However, the design and access statement reads: ldquoSince this permission was obtained, despite evidence of marketing, there has been insufficient interest for its use as shops and flats.ldquoOur clientsrsquo proposal is to redevelop the building for use as a hostel, providing accommodation to visitors to Dunbar, [primarily] those who would take part in the large number of outdoor activities available within the area.ldquoA small flat-roofed single-storey extension to the side is proposed to provide associated laundry room.

title: tranent-39-s-scott-glynn-retires-after-dinner-circuit

He had a liver transplant in .Tributes and testimonies to his talent have been pouring in across social media, with many quoting lines from his routine, as well as lsquoget well soonrsquo and lsquokeep fightingrsquo messages.A Crowdfunding page has been set up to support Scott - the founder of the hugely successfulWalk with Scott charity treks -and has raised more than pound, so far.Anyone wishigto donate should visit justgiving crowdfunding davie-martin-

title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: dog-walker-stalker-sentenced-next-year
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he spotted her Labradoodle allegedly becoming overly-friendly with his greyhound-cross while out on a walk with his pet.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their dog out for walks in the town.The woman was forced to call the police and, after denying the allegations, Page, of Castle Street, eventually stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year.He was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following the trial last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last week.However, when Page appeared in court, the sherf again deferred sentence on him to January next year.

title: great-music-tap-belhaven-brewery-hosts-300th-birthday-festival
story: The Belhaven th Birthday Bash features household names including Dougie Mac-Lean and Capercaillie, as well as up-and-coming bands such as Assynt and Kinnaris Quintet.The special event, which takes place in Dunbar on September , is being billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish music and beer.Gordon Muir, marketing controller and festival organiser, said: ldquoItrsquos not every year you get to mark a milestone as big as  years and so we wanted to celebrate this with Belhavenrsquos two loves, beer and Scottish music.ldquoBelhavenrsquos th Birthday Bash is the ultimate party for those fans and our loyal customers who enjoy nothing more than a few beers and great live music.ldquoWersquove plenty of things for the whole family to do, including storytelling and games for youngsters, selfie sessions and music masterclasses for the teens, and beer tastings and brewery tours for the adults.The main stage showcases the best in Scottish traditional music and top talent from Scotlandrsquos folk scene over the last three decades.Multi-award-winning Scottish contemporary folk band Breabach are joined by Highland outfit Tide Lines Niteworks, who have become renowned for their fusion of electronica and folk music and Elephant Sessions and Talisk ndash both winners of Belhavenrsquos annual bursary for innovation in Scottish music.Belhaven Breweryrsquos beers will be served from tap bars around the brewery grounds, including , a specially brewed birthday celebration pale ale. There will be food stalls and merchandise stalls.Meanwhile, the brewery gardens host family activities and music masterclasses.Gates open at am, with the first act taking to the stage at noon.The following day, the brewery is hosting an open day between am and pm.More information at belhaven birthday-bash

title: flexible-fundraiser-flips-along-belhaven-bay-help-charity
story: Hugh Panton literally went head over heels to help Friends of the Earth Scotland as he backflipped for a mile along Belhaven Bay.The -year-old, who lives just a mile from the beach, on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, told the Courier: ldquoI was graduating from the University of Aberdeen and wanted to do something a bit special.ldquoI have always wanted to do a fundraiser event but never really had the time when I was at university.ldquoI decided I would do something that capitalises on my skills as a flipping enthusiast and had a couple of ideas.ldquoI thought maybe I would try to do , flips in five days or something and then it just came to me to try to do a mile of flips.ldquoAt the time, it sounded quite ridiculous but I really wanted to try it.The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil spent three days last month working his way from west to east along the picturesque beach for the challenge, which took him about  hours to complete.Hugh, who has started work as an assistant countryside ranger at the Loch of the Lowes Nature Reserve, near Dunkeld, was not the only one on the beach, as he attracted curious glances from onlookers.Hugh, who studied geography at university, managed to raise more than pound, and said: ldquoI would go down to the bay and I go to the very far end where there are not too many people.ldquoAfter a wee while training before doing the event, people would be walking by and their heads just slowly started following me down the beach.ldquoThere were horse riders as well and the horses did not like it at all and I would have to wait for them to pass.The flips were broken down into blocks of five or  so Hugh could keep his bearings, with the talented tumbler completing about  flips over each of the three days ndash  in total.Kerrigan Bell, development manager for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Hugh decided to raise much-needed funds.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Scotlands National AirshowBIG crowds are expected to flock to the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune on Saturday as Scotlandrsquos National Airshow takes place.And as well as all the aircraft initially announced, there are some exciting new additions to the line-up for the airshow, which takes place between am and pm, with the aerial displays set to commence from .pm.Despite todays poor weather, organisers said this morningthat the Met Office forecast "showednothing to prevent the Airshow going ahead today as planned".A Wildcat HMA  maritime attack helicopter,  Catalina flying boat and a  North American T Texan training aircraft are among the newbies.Joining them in their debut at the airshow are a Second World War Soviet Yakovlev Yak- fighter, a Westland Scout helicopter and a de Havilland Beaver utility aircraft.Also in the mix at the airshow are a Goodyear Corsair FG-D US wartime fighter bomber, Canadian T- Silver Star jet and an American P Thunderbolt Second World War fighter, while five members of the Wings Parachute Display Team drop in.As well as all the new additions, the aerial entertainment programme includes the RAFrsquos Supermarine Spitfire, Hawker Hurricane and Avro Lancaster from the RAF Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, as well as the modern-day Typhoon fighter jet.Aerobatic display team The Blades will take to the skies along with the AeroSuperBatics Wingwalkers, both performing some breathtaking tricks plus, much, much more.Tickets can be bought online, by calling    or on the gate on the day. Visit nms.ac.uk airshow for more details.. North Berwick Leboat FeteTHERErsquoS plenty of fun on offer this Saturday as North Berwick Leboat Fete takes place.The event, which runs between .pm and pm, starts with a parade along High Street before the crowning of this yearrsquos Leboat Queen, Theodora Nikolova, by Lady Dalrymple.The fete at Elcho Green and West Beach then opens at pm, with ious stalls and games on offer and a raffle.. Spott FeteAFTERNOON tea, games for children, stalls and music are all promised at Spott Village Fete.Teas are served in the village hall, with the event held on The Glebe from pm to pm.. Gullane GamesA WEEK of celebrations s to Gullane as the annual Gullane Games kicks off on Saturday and runs until next Saturday .The opening day is packed with sport ndash featuring golf, football and hockey.The under-srsquo golf competition starts at am on the childrenrsquos course.Football for under-s begins at pm at Memorial Park and P- hockey gets under way at .pm on the astroturf.Sunday sees a village treasure hunt from pm at the Mallard Hotel. Entry is pound per team, with maximum of five members per team children in primary school must be accompanied by an adult.. Musselburgh FestivalMUSSELBURGH festival is well under way, and there is still much to look forward to with fairground rides, fancy dress, a raft race and parades still on the horizon.Horses will be seen parading through the town tomorrowmorning as the traditional Rideout takes place,starting at am at Pinkie Pillars.While Pinkie St Peterrsquos Playing Field hosts Saturdayrsquos Festival Fun Day, with fairground rides, stalls, face painting, music and childrenrsquos entertainment filling the day with enjoyment for everyone.Festival Day will be capped with the even grander Festival Ball. Tickets are for sale at pound and can be purchased by contacting musselburghfestivalball@gmailSunday sees the fun continue as the Fisherrow Family Fun Day takes place at the harbour , featuring beach volleyball, beach rugby and beach tennis hand in hand with sandcastle competitions, crafts, a tug of war and a raft race.The Honest Lass and Honest Lad this year are Claire Dougal and Aidan Maguire, who have been busy throughout the week with their attendant Abbie Thomson.There have also been appearances from last yearrsquos Honest Lad and Honest Lass, Conor Scott and Katie McLaren.For more information about this yearrsquos festival, visit musselburghfestival.org

title: dunbar-39-s-bear-statue-expected-place-later-year
story: Discussions surrounding an eye-catching piece of artwork near the A have been ongoing for several years.Original proposals suggested Apollo, the Greek and Roman god of the sun, could find a home on the Spott Road roundabout on the busy road.However, it was eventually decided a bear would be located nearby.Renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott ndash responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk ndash is the man behind the -foot bear, which will stand on its hind legs.Dunbar Community Council said it had received confirmation from applicants Hallhill Development Ltd that work should start towards the end of September and last for five weeks.East Lothian Council initially refused planning permission for the sculpture, which will be near the townrsquos Asda and McDonaldrsquos, but approval was finally given by the Scottish Government, with conditions from Transport Scotland.Ken Ross, from the applicants, previously told the Courier: ldquoThis piece of art will not only contribute to the emerging identity of Dunbarrsquos new gateway but has the potential to draw people into the area to find out more about John Muir.

title: revamped-aubigny-swimming-pool-revealed
story: Work got under way at the pool and health suite within the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre in April and ndash after a delay ndash the pool re-opened on Monday.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which manages the sports centre, was confident visitors would be impressed with the changes.He said: ldquoIn my view, the only way to improve it would be to knock it down and start from scratch, which was not an option for us.ldquoIn terms of the amount of work and the quality of the work carried out, I think you will be absolutely delighted.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works have been carried out at the sports centre over several weeks.During the work, the two pools were drained, with a new light, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.New lighting, roofing works and ceiling and wall cladding work has been carried out surrounding the pool, with new lockers and other alterations in the changing rooms.Tiles were also given a thorough clean ahead of the re-opening.The new-look pool was revealed to enjoyleisure members and politicians last Friday.Among those attending the opening was East Lothian MP Martin Whitfield, along with Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillors Shamin Akhtar and Craig Hoy.Ms Akhtar was impressed with what she saw and said: ldquoI am delighted with the work.ldquoThe swimming pool looks absolutely fantastic.ldquoI think it will be really well received by the local community and I think it is going to be really well used.Ward colleague Mr Hoy agreed, saying: ldquoItrsquos fantastic to see the Aubigny pool re-opening and to see an entirely new look awaiting local residents.ldquoPools and sports centres arenrsquot just leisure facilities, they are le savers ndash helping our communities fight chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease.ldquoItrsquos vital we continue to invest in our gyms and swimming pools in East Lothian.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centres and originally opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in September . The site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Before the temporary closure, the facility welcomed about , bathers each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.

title: attempts-bring-bugs-back-john-muir-way
story: Charity Bugle Scotland aims to boost insect and bug numbers along or near the Dunbar-to-Helensburgh John Muir Way by encouraging wildflower-rich habitats at selected sites.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThe UK has lost over  per cent of species-rich grassland since the s with dramatic declines in associated wildle including native bees, butterflies, hoverflies and beetles.Phase two of the pollinator project has recently been completed.There were  habitat sites in total that were seeded and rewilded, including four sites in East Lothian: Prestongrange Museum, by Prestonpans Cockenzie Primary School Longniddry Wood and at Waterston House, Aberlady.A new wildflower meadow was created on-site at Prestongrange Museum with help from the staff and volunteers Cockenzie Primary teachers and pupils lent a helping hand to create a bee garden in the school grounds and wildflower seeds were distributed to Waterston House to enhance their existing wildle garden and orchard. At Longniddry Wood, the charity worked with East Lothian Council to plant new bulbs and seeds.All of the habitats along or close to the John Muir Way were supported by funding from the Scottish Government and the Greggs Foundation, as well as the Central Scotland Green Network and the local authorities.Joanna Lindsay, conservation officer for Bugle Scotland said: ldquoCommunities all along the John Muir Way have contributed to enhancing their local greenspaces for wildle through this project and have learned about the importance of protecting our pollinator populations. Hopefully this time next year, walkers and cyclists using the route will enjoy seeing these sites buzzing with le.Roseanna Cunningham MSP, Environment Secretary, added: ldquoIrsquom pleased to support initiatives like this which help to create ideal habitats for our flora and fauna.

title: east-lothian-town-features-charlie-laidlaw-39-s-new-book
story: The Space Between Time uses Edinburgh, as well as North Berwick, in its story.Gullane author Charlie Laidlaw was pleased to say his second book ndash following on the heels of The Things We Learn When Wersquore Dead ndash had already attracted praise from reviewers.He said: ldquo[Before its official release] it had something like  reviews on Goodreads and all have been four or five stars.ldquoThat is encouraging because when you write a book you have confidence in it but you have no idea what kind of reaction other people will have to it.ldquoWhat  is encouraging is that the rights to an audio book and large print version have been snapped up.Actress Kate Okello, who starred in Stan  Ollie, will narrate the newly-released book.The Space Between Time, which has been published by Accent Press, tells the story of a young girl growing up in a dysal family and ultimately coming to terms with herself.Emma is the daughter of a beautul and loving mother, and her father is one of the most famous film actors of his generation.She is also the granddaughter of an eccentric and obscure Italian astrophysicist.But as her seemingly charmed le begins to unravel, and Emma experiences love and tragedy, she ultimately finds solace in her once-derided grandfatherrsquos theorem on the universe.The story offers the metaphor that everyone is connected, even to those that have been loved and not quite lost.Charlie, , says his books are ldquocharacter driven, with plans for a third book ndash Love Potions and Other Calamities ndash due to be released later this year.The Space Between Time has been three years in the making, with Charlie having to fit writing in around running his own media consultancy business in the county.He said: ldquoI carry around a notebook with me andan idea comes to me I will put it down.

title: tranent-woman-honoured-pope-services-catholic-church
story: Fiona Stewart, now resident of Banff in Aberdeenshire, was awarded the Benemerenti Medal for her  years of service to the church.Fiona has been singing at Tranentrsquos St Martinrsquos RC Church since she was eight, later playing guitar at services, and continued to do so throughout her teenage years and even came back on weekends when she studied at the University of Dundee.After moving to Banff in the early s, Fiona, , dedicated herself to her job as a senior solicitor at Aberdeen Council and to Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Banff ndash as secretary of the parish council, chair of the finance committee and  years as chief musician.This commitment to her church and its parish was recognised by the congregation, who nominated her.The nomination then went to the Bishop, who agreed, and took the request to Rome, where he collected the Papal award for Fiona, surprising her with it last month.She said: ldquoI had no idea this was happening. I was getting ready to play the guitar for the end of service when Father Colin Stewart presented me with the award.ldquoI was in shock, there was a large applause, and I was just shaking my head thinking lsquono wayrsquo!ldquoI was presented with a medal and a framed certicate from the Pope, and the congregation had made me a cake shaped like a guitar, which was really lovely. We had a tea party to celebrate.ldquoIrsquom still really taken aback. People kept saying to me lsquoit usually gets presented to really old people and rarely to womenrsquo so you can imagine how proud I am to have received it.ldquoMy parents are also really proud and astonished!ldquoI canrsquot wait for my visit to see them and come back to St Martinrsquos to play and sing, as I always do when Irsquom through. Itrsquos part of who I am, and I love coming back.Fionarsquos parents, William and Zuzanna Stewart, live on Tranent High Street.
